courses.course_desc: Course provides an overview of black culture in America from an interdisciplinary approach, employing scholarship from history, literature, music, visual and performing arts, folklore, religion, sociology, psychology, philosophy, economics, and political science.  It introduces epistemological considerations, theories, and methods that form the field of African American and African Diaspora Studies. (MULT).
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_desc: This course examines Black American cinema between 1919 and the present and how film can help society better understand black history, black culture, and the black experience in America. The course also explores what each film teaches Blacks about Blacks and what film teaches Whites and other groups about Blacks.
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_desc: This course will introduce students to the historical study of Black LGBTQ peoples. We will use primary sources such as letters, diaries, newspaper articles, and blues songs, along with historical and interdisciplinary scholarship and films, to learn about the experiences of same-sex loving and gender-transgressing Black people. (WI).
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_desc: This course examines how Black Americans have negotiated the Black-White color line from the 1800s to the present day.
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_name: Global Perspectives on the African Diaspora
courses.course_desc: Course connects the transatlantic slave trade, contemporary migrations, their legacies, and speaks to the broader issues of the African diaspora in relation to previous and ongoing struggles of black people for rebirth, progress, justice, and racial uplift.  Examines African Diasporic womens definition of feminism while suggesting no universal black feminism. (MULT).
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_name: Intersections of Race, Class, Gender, and Sexualities
courses.course_desc: This course critically examines how race, class, gender, and sexuality intersect to shape the lived experiences of a wide array of communities in the United States. Students cannot receive credit for both WS 4377 and AAS 4377. (WI) Prerequisite: AAS 2310 with a grade of "D" or better.
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours

courses.course_name: Independent Research in African American Studies
courses.course_desc: Independent study course open to advanced students on an individual or small group basis. The research area in African American Studies, bibliography, and study paper outline are to be approved by the instructor.
courses.course_credits:
3 Credit Hours 
3 Lecture Contact Hours 
0 Lab Contact Hours
